Comment: "...shut it down and die."

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Maybe replace it with global representatives from the 150 or so National Conferences of Bishops representing 1.2 billion Catholics? I don't know. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. If courts jailed a few bishops, that might help a lot, too.

Comment: If you think putting Alaska Natives in charge of ANY natural resource will provide any degree of protection or conservation, you apparently do not read much. Check out the history of the Kilbuck caribou herd. Or, if you really want an education, go to Bethel in May and June when the Kuskokwim delta is filled with ducks and geese tending their nests. You can watch fifteen or twenty boats go out there every morning and spend the day killing ducks and geese even though it is totally illegal and unethical, until their boats are literally full, then coming back to town, taking a dozen or two home for supper, coming back the next day, dumping the other hundred or so dead birds out of the boat and going back out to blast a couple hundred more. Yep, they are definitely "Stewards of the Land" alright. Or go do a census of game within 30 miles of ANY village in NW or SW Alaska. No moose, no caribou. If it moves, kill it. If it flies it dies.

Comment: "who do you think should do the killing?"

Anyone and everyone. This is a community problem, so everyone who wants to be part of the solution should be allowed to help. As I said above: remove all protections on free ranging cats, and allow people to help. People who allow their pets to roam outside are part of the problem, because their pets are part of the problem. It would be very sad if pets were killed, but ultimately it is the owner's responsibility to make sure their pets are not out killing birds.

Years ago some Vermont acquaintances got one warning from the Ranger: Next time I see your dog running deer, I'll shoot it. Next time she saw it running deer, she did. 

Vermont does not pretend that trapping, neutering, and releasing dogs solves any problems. They are serious about threats. We just want to feel good about ourselves. If we were serious about feral cats, we would kill them. Neutered cats eat birds. Don't release them. Kill them.

Comment: The formal Catholic teaching rests on a very interesting point, that once understood ties a lot of things together.  

This point is that God isn't bound by space and time.  

Some Protestants get themselves wrapped in loops trying to explain Scripture and matters such as predestination, free will, etc.  And many Catholics do too.

Jesus's sacrifice occurred in space and time, but its effects aren't.   

The role and idea of priesthood in the OT wasn't wrong, so much as it was imperfect.   Jesus became the perfect priest (and perfect victim).

So Catholic priests participate in the priesthood of Jesus Christ by lending God their all. 

So the priesthood continues.

And the "common priesthood" (you and me) continues as well. We can share in the intimate union with Jesus by offering Him our work, our struggles, our joys, etc.   We "partake" in this act of charity with Him, just as Simon of Cyrene did (in a particular point in space and time).

Comment: Mark, you raise an important point about affordability. I'll get to that in a second. First though, there is a big distinction between intercity high-speed rail (HSR) and intrAcity grade-separated rail. Honolulu is not building HSR, they are building a grade-separated metro rail system. Think of it as a subway but elevated. The advantage of these systems over at-grade light rail are that 1) they travel faster between stations (up to 55mph) since there are no traffic lights, cars, bikes or peds to avoid, 2) they can have longer trains (at-grade trains are restricted by the minimum city block lengths), and 3) they can operate with shorter headways (more frequent).  These advantages add up to roughly double the average speed (30 vs 15mph) and around 4 times the maximum operating capacity (ppl/hr/direction).  HSR is a totally different beast. It goes over 200mph and stations are often hundreds of miles apart.

Comment: The Alaska Supreme Court's decision that Permanent Fund dividends are not an entitlement from a dedicated fund but an appropriation issue supports the approach by Mr. Bradner. Using what we have first before enacting new taxes is the approach of a good steward. Sadly, many people treat the PFD as an entitlement despite the court's decision that is firmly based on our state constitution. Because of this attitude, those same people consider a smaller appropriation for the PFD as a "taking."  However, the PFD is an expenditure of state funds and that use of state funds must compete and be balanced against all other needs. A smaller PFD is not a taking, but should be the result of a careful and thoughtful process by the governor and the legislature to meet state needs from a smaller treasury.

Comment: Seattle based filmmakers from Rooted in Rights made a documentary on workers with disabilities who are paid subminimum wages. In the past year, it has been shown at around Seattle at the SIFF Uptown, Starbucks HQ, Seattle University, and the University of Washington as well as at hundreds of other locations across the country, including Capitol Hill in DC. It is now available to stream or download for those who want to get to know what it is like for workers with disabilities who are paid below minimum wage and compare that to others who are treated fairly. https://vimeo.com/ondemand/bottomdollars
There is a growing movement across this country supporting the elimination of subminimum wages for people with disabilities, but very few jurisdictions have actually done it. It is great that Seattle is looking to lead the way here in Washington.

Alberta has a low royalty rate for bitumen compared to rates in countries that have similar heavy oil resources.
 Alberta, for example, takes from 25 to 40 per cent of profit, equivalent to 10 per cent of gross revenue. 
In contrast, Venezuela, which also extracts heavy oil, takes 40 per cent of gross revenue -- four times as much as Alberta.
Saudi Arabia captures 85 per cent of profits from its oil fields, while Norway takes 80 per cent of profit -- both three times as much as Alberta. 
Newfoundland/Hibernia takes 30 to 50 per cent of profit, plus 7.5 per cent of gross revenue or twice as much as Alberta.

Comment: Read up before you make a bigger fool of yourself.

" . . . . Aquinas distinguishes four kinds of law: (1) eternal law; (2) natural law; (3) human law; and (4) divine law.   Eternal law is comprised of those laws that govern the nature of an eternal universe; as Susan Dimock (1999, 22) puts it, one can "think of eternal law as comprising all those scientific (physical, chemical, biological, psychological, etc.) 'laws' by which the universe is ordered." Divine law is concerned with those standards that must be satisfied by a human being to achieve eternal salvation. One cannot discover divine law by natural reason alone; the precepts of divine law are disclosed only through divine revelation."

The natural law is comprised of those precepts of the eternal law that govern the behavior of beings possessing reason and free will. . . ."

http://www.iep.utm.edu/natlaw/

"United States Signals Intelligence Directive

Legal Compliance and U.S. Persons Minimization Procedures

Comment: I'm all for teaching children to be independent and self-sufficient, but I'd be quite leery about sending kids aged 7-11 alone on a city transit bus... and it has nothing to do with finding their right bus or recognizing their stops. Kids nowadays are pretty savvy when it comes to numbers and directions.

The Govt of BC won't come out and mention the actual reason why unsupervised kids under 10 can't be on buses or why 12-year-olds can't supervise them. But here's the reason: Bus crazies.

I've ridden on a lot of transit buses in big cities and the common thing about all of them is that, at any given time, there are probably 1-4 people on any given bus who have been in and out of jail or a mental health institution. As an adult, you learn the nuances of moving around them, ignoring them, or, in some cases, out-intimidating them. 

But those kinds of street smarts are way beyond an elementary-school-aged kid yelling "stranger-danger!" This urban-parenting blogger should know that.

Comment: I have been watching a lot of Rockies games on the opponent's TV feed this season and I agree, there are not a lot of great TV crews out there. And I suppose if I watched enough of other team's feeds I could identify a crew that was worse than the Rockies guys. But no matter which way you slice it, I'd put the Rockies crew right near the bottom of a pretty bad bunch. 

Between Goodman's attempts to present himself as a savvy baseball insider, to the often little-league level "analysis" put forth by his boothmate, to Goodman's bad and extremely annoying habit of telling us what we're about to see rather than what we just saw, to the general talk-down-ish approach to the entire broadcast as if Rockies fans were still new to the game... they are just really, really bad. I could deal with a half inning talking about ice cream or interviewing a football coach or Spilly playing in the scoreboard if the bulk of the broadcast was solid, but it's truly one of the worst productions in the game.

Comment: The full and final analysis of just what happened in this recent campaign and the results of the election is a while off yet.  All of this reporting, including in the secular media, are snapshots of the facts and not yet the entire picture.  It is far too soon for that.  We are in Reactive mode - still working-through the shock/surprise and trying find explanations and answers to what the future holds.  Our talk - on both sides - is "stress talk,"  highly emotional and coming from all sides (of which there are many!).  But let me offer one overriding idea for those of us who were/are anti-Trump et al.  We need to allow this administration to unfold and become what it may.  In doing so we will allow them to show who they really are, how damaging they will be to the nation both internal and external, and let them all crash and burn in chaos and in-fighting and condemnation from their own party as well as from others.  It has already started.  Trump, etc. are a mess as I write this.

Comment: As I note in my paper on why the Bank of Canada should lower its target rate of inflation:
http://economics.ca/2017/papers/BA0017-1.pdf
it appears that the US Fed has been following a much lower target rate than 2% on a de facto basis since it formally established a target rate and the PCEPI as its target indicator in January 2012. From January 2012 through April 2017, the annualized inflation rate has been 1.2%. Nor is there any reason for the US Fed to have a 2% target rate. The Canadian CPI has substantial upper-level substitution bias, which probably added at least 0.5 percentage points to the inflation rate in 1995, when the 2% target rate became effective at the Bank of Canada. The PCEPI due to its chain Fisher formula has virtually eliminated upper level substitution bias. The formal consistency with Canada in choosing a 2% target rate was logically inconsistent. Targeting the same true rate of inflation required a lower target rate, no more than 1.5%.

Comment: I'm not opposed to tariffs being applied when trade occurs between a nation with strong labor protections, a healthy welfare system, higher wages, and stronger environmental/safety laws and another nations that is lacking in one or more of these areas. Imposing tariffs on nations for these reasons motivates those nations to improve standards while making nations with high standards more competitive, thereby decreasing the race to the bottom.  Tariffs then, should be applied to improve labour and environmental standards and end the race to the bottom, not to pursue some  America First strategy, but tariffs do have a time and a place, and in the auto industry under NAFTA, I support tariffs if done for these reasons.

Comment: Where does all the money go that is given by taxpayers to indigenous communities? The only reports provided by the mainstream media focus on alleged under funding in certain areas. But if examined on the basis of total funding per capita to indigenous communities, aboriginal communities receive far, far more than is provided to non-aboriginals. For example, Nunavut (created to be a model of aboriginal self-government) receives per capita annual funding from the federal taxpayers of $42,055 (yes, that's right, a family of four in Nunavut receives annual support of $168,000 from federal taxpayers). That compares to the per-capita funding from the federal government for all Canadians of $1,986. Federal funding for Nunavut per capita is over 20 times greater than the average for all Canadians. How meaningful, then, would any claim be that Nunavut is underfunded in one given area of government services?

Get up early so your defense can be more aggressive; rely on that defense to create turnovers or points; rely on the defense to keep the opponent off the board or to field goals; have a solid running game that keys to his play action strength; play mistake free on offense.

Unfortunately, not every game is going to play out this way and when it doesn't his weaknesses become even more exposed.

Comment: Not quite.  

Gratian (1150-ish) tried to harmonize laws already extant at the time.  Catechesis has gone on, as the history of the name implies, for a significant portion of Christian history, though generally by the bishop or through his auspices.  The Roman Catechism was much influenced by Aquinas', developed almost 350 years earlier.

The benefit of having both a Code of Canon Law and a catechism is that most people can read them for themselves, now.  Just as, prior to John West's publishing of case law, the US legal system was difficult to navigate and precedent difficult to find, so the canons used in various jurisdictions across the world were difficult to reconcile.  The catechism, also, is not the sum of the Catholic faith; it is its summary.  Sufficient to answer a question about "what" the church teaches, but the "why" of that teaching requires significantly more diligence and study.

Comment: This tax is NOT a % of your federal tax.  It's a flat tax of 1.5% on wages. Go back and reread the article.

Furthermore, it's not just rich people who pay federal income taxes.
A single person making an Adjusted Gross Income of $20K a year pays $1,581 in federal taxes. That's somebody who makes $9.61/hour and works full time.
A married couple making $40K filing jointly pays $1,948 in federal taxes.
A married couple with two kids making $40K filing jointly pays $1,110.
If only 45.3% of Americans pay taxes, it only illustrates how many people are living in poverty.

http://www.dinkytown.net/java/Tax1040.html

Comment: Now we're going to hear the same whinging whining from bittorrent users complaining that Shaw prioritizing it's IPTV over regular internet traffic in QoS schedules and how it doesn't effect bandwidth caps violates net neutrality as when Telus released Optik.  Yawn.

Bittorrent is the most destructive application for internet traffic that exists.  It has collosal overhead per packet, distributes millions of packets per hour across networks all over the place in a giant messy spider's web and runs havoc on routers in the ISPs backbone trying to ensure decent quality of service for customers who want a reliable, low latency stream.

That's not to say it isnt without it's uses, but it's default settings are unlimited inbound connections and unlimited bandwidth outbound, and the majority of ill informed users use the default because they just want to download a pirated movie.  Then they get upset when their ISP cuts them off because the moved a terabyte over nothing.

Comment: I don't miss Christmas per se, but I do miss parts of it. I remember Christmas being about special decorations and extraordinary light displays in some neighborhoods. I remember the Mitch Miller sing alongs - Must Be Santa. Advent calendars, caroling, Christmas parties with hot mulled cider and egg nog. A nativity scene here and there and some family members went to Mass. 
I remember a cease fire during the Viernam War, "so that no mother would learn that her son had been killed on Christmas."
I remember when stores didn't get out Christmas decorations until after Thanksgiving, and I only had to tolerate about a week of non-stop Christmas music on the radio. 
I don't know when the war was declared on who owns this day. During my youth it wasn't touted as the most Holiest of Days. Sure, we knew about the manger and the wise guys and the star of Bethlehem. "Merry Christmas" is what Santa shouted as his sleigh took off. It meant "Merry Christmas" as in "to all, and to all a good night."

Comment: The Manhattan Project -- the most closely guarded military secret of WWII -- wasn't about developing a more efficient way to destroy manufacturing sites. Robert Oppenheimer understood that, Roosevelt and Truman understood that and I understand that.

In another post you said the people of Nagasaki and Hiroshima were warned "long" before the bombs were dropped. Now you admit it was "shortly" before. But what you left out was that by most credible accounts they got conventional bomb warnings, the same kind the military had used before. The people were led to believe that if they stayed away from military targets, they'd be safe. They quickly learned otherwise.

What the Islamists do to civilians is reprehensible. But if we are to make a sound argument as to our own moral superiority, we must come to terms -- honestly and courageously -- with our historic mistakes. Rationalizing Hiroshima and Nagasaki as morally justifiable will always be a stumbling block to that effort. Always.

Comment: There is a TEENY problem with that solution as it is contrary to the international treaties and conventions to which Canada is signatory and which have been passed into our domestic law in the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

Based on the SCOC decision of over three decades ago in Singh v. Minister of Employment and Immigration, [1985] 1 S.C.R. 177 the Charter would also present a bit of a hurdle.

"Per Dickson C.J. and Lamer and Wilson JJ.: Appellants, in the determination of their claims, are entitled to assert the protection of s. 7  of the Charter  which guarantees "everyone ... the right to life, liberty and security of the person and the right not to be deprived thereof except in accordance with the principles of fundamental justice". The term "everyone" in s. 7  includes every person physically present in Canada and by virtue of such presence amenable to Canadian law."

We lost control of health care costs in the late 1940's when "group health insurance" was introduced as a way to circumvent government wage controls.  Once we started spending someone else's money for health care, the costs have soared continuously.  It's become a boondoggle for the drug, hospital, and insurance industry because nobody cares what the charges are.

The only areas in health care where the costs are coming down are elective procedures that aren't covered by insurance.  Competition controls prices.

Comment: When was the last time anyone had an engine failure?  Do you even know someone who has had an engine failure?  I change the oil on my truck some unknown time after the oil change notification comes on and I have over 400,000 km on my truck without an engine repair.  The typical distance is 15,000 km between changes.  Modern engines simply do not fail with reasonable maintenance and most people spend money changing the oil excessively for no reason.  Changing the oil is for the next owner so wasting money on excessive oil changes makes no sense.  If you lease a vehicle for two or three years and then give them back, don't waste your money doing any maintenance at all.  If you decide that your existing vehicle has only a couple of years left in it, then again, stop doing maintenance.  My old minivan hit 350,000 km and I did no maintenance at all for three years then sold it at auction for $500.

Comment: What to expect?  That is simple:

- More red tape for business and therefore higher labour costs
- Higher labour costs will be passed on to workers in the form of lower wages (by means of lower pay raises)
- In the case where wages are somehow governed externally (eg. minimum wage) and therefore can't go lower it will result in less hiring
- The latter scenario will mainly affect young workers leading to higher youth unemployment
- Lower income for workers and higher youth unemployment both mean slower economic growth

There really isn't much else that CAN happen with this kind of thing.

Comment: Robert Wight is wrong to imply that officers in Vietnam were given preferential treatment by being rotated to the rear after six months of field duty while enlisted men were required to serve their full tour in the field.  It is true that some platoon leaders and company commanders were reassigned to fill vacancies on battalion and brigade staffs but that hardly was the “rear” because they still operated from fire bases surrounded by enemy territory.  Moreover, the number of officer positions on battalion, brigade and division staffs was a fraction of the number at company level, which severely limited the opportunities for lieutenants and captains to rotate out of the field.  Thus, most company-grade officers (lieutenants and captains in the Army), served their entire tours in field units.  Most enlisted soldiers in Vietnam were in field units like infantry, armor and artillery, had almost no opportunities to rotate out, and did give their very best for their entire tour in Nam.

Comment: Please read a little history of the origins of the notwithstanding clause. It has its origins in  Diefenbaker's Bill of Rights (section 2). The notwithstanding clause, S.33 of the Constitution of 1982 was a significant limitation of the powers and rights that could be over-ridden in the Bill of Rights.

Pierre Elliot Trudeau hated the idea of the notwithstanding clause and refused to consider it. It was only included in the Constitution at the '11th hour' by Chretien as a compromise to gain the support of provincial premiers.

Comment: The concept of covering one's face in public, as a marker of respectability and of a class that can afford to be modest, is deep in Anglo culture and we maintain it symbolically today.

My grandmother (I'm 5th-gen Brit Cdn) grew up when ALL respectable women wore a hat with a veil in public. A bride's veil is a relic of that. Or search "hat veil" to find hundreds of pics of (white, anglo) women with a minimalist version, including Princess Diana at her coronation, Queen Elizabeth at any formal outdoor event. A princess costume has a hat with a long draping veil. Search "medieval veil" to see the more extensive & opaque covering that remained part of a nun's habit until a few decades ago.

By contrast a "bare-faced" lie is a brazen lie, a naked lie, a lie without shame. To be bare-faced is to be "unconcealed" (c. 1600) in a bad sense, "shameless, audacious" (1670s).

Comment: The more important point is that the ASD still has too many facilities to maintain for the size of the declining student population. 

The district has added 1.2million square feet of new neighborhood elementary schools with over 250 new classrooms with FEWER students than were attending those schools in the mid 1980s. That unneeded facility growth is robbing resources from school operations that could fund 200 teaching positions. 

That said --This is a pretty reasonable bond package. Just urgent maintenance needs. No new facilities. The ASD currently has about $450 million in deferred maintenance. This bond package will not reduce the deferred maintenance backlog; it will just keep the backlog growing more slowly. 

Bottom line-- I'll support this bond package but my patience is growing very thin with the districts inability to effectively manage their over abundance of facilities

Comment: Speaking as a regular Kwiaht volunteer, I want to encourage people to check out our website, indanisland.info, to find out more about the species we monitor and help protect at the island, and to join us in our volunteer work. We are out there nearly every tide that's low enough to walk out without wading (April to August) and you don't have to have special training in order to help out. Our volunteer calendar will be found on the website closer to the new season. Thanks, Mandi, for such a thorough article summing up a complex presentation. Just one thing, though: our pal "Bertha", who we didn't see last summer, was actually a short-spined star that would often be seen submerged in one small area of the eelgrass meadow, recognizable for the pink color of the species, which are much larger than ochre stars. The absence represents diminished species diversity in the sea stars we're seeing.

Comment: "...great cloud of witnesses and the power of intercession...."

Quite true, Jay Edward. The writer Flannery O'Connor probably best understood this "cloud of witnesses," among other things, this Catholic mist whose vast assemblage and grace-filled multitude in the past was created by ordinary folk who venerated them -- in spite of the experts, the priests, the theologians. By  contrast, the virtues of O'Connor's good respectable "Christian folk" like Mrs. Turpin (see short story, "Revelation") were the vices of Catholic saints, "virtues" to be avoided, expunged from their Christ-like witnessing. By the end of the story, those "virtues" (in Mrs.Turpin's epiphany) had to be burnt from Mrs. Turpin's kind of people before making it into Paradise, before linking up with the communion of saints (people, from Mrs. Turpin's perspective, who were ugly, paralleled in physical deformity -- in bodily appearance, parts, in the tracks of lines, blemishes on their faces -- to low life and murderers).

Comment: The "ban panhandling" movement is not new.  It has been proposed, adopted and frequently found unConstitutional in many communities.  To me, it is a simplistic solution to a complex problem.  It addresses the "result" of a multitude of problems in today's society.  It is an "end-run" to force panhandling back "into the shadows, but does nothing to address the presenting issues which lead individuals to panhandle.  

Supporters of such bans usually refer to giving panhandlers money, food, or whatever, as "enabling" behavior; often with specific reference to addictions: drugs or alcoholism.  Does it allow addicts and chronic alcoholics to continue such behavior? Yes, it does.  Does "successful" banning of panhandling, "cure" addiction and alcoholism?  Of course not.

Both conditions require extensive treatment....usually residential...and guaranteed to be very expensive.  When we provide the availability of such services to the destitute, I'll be happy to support bans of panhandling.

Comment: When I first entered the business world, an advertising agency in London, in the mid-fifties I could write a letter - or more precisely dictate a letter to be typed by a secretary from shorthand - in the morning which would be posted and delivered elsewhere in London by the afternoon of the same day. The recipient would respond and I'd receive his reply (it most often was his since females were confined to the secretarial pool) the next day. Most business was carried out by mail, not telephone. When that changed and the telephone became the favoured option, things began to speed up. I had less time to think about my reply ... and that one move began the remorseless increase in speed necessary to do business - through telex, then fax, then e-mail and so on until there was little time to think and business suffered.
I can relate, Margaret.

Comment: Lyme disease is fortunately rare in Oregon. What are not rare, however, are quacks who do not believe in science.  

Real lyme disease is treatable with a short course of antibiotics, even if caught late. After treatment, the infection has been wiped out, so there is no treatment other than time for any lingering symptoms. Lyme testing is also very accurate a few weeks after infection. 

There is a strong scientific consensus regarding the diagnosis and treatment of lyme disease, but "chronic lyme" has become a popular fake diagnosis with the help of shady labs and alternative medicine quacks, called "lyme literate". Vocal groups like Oregon Lyme Disease Network promote pseudoscience, conspiracy theories, and quackery. They also tell sad stories that often do not stand up to scrutiny since they contradict known science. 

We should empathize with Lyme Truthers but not feed their delusion. We should also protect the public from the snake oil salesmen who prey on the innocent.

Comment: I don't think liking the Tridentine mass has any causal connection with thinking  that AL "propagates heresy"; but the Lefebvrists are marked not only by their liturgical tastes but also by their rejection of the teaching of Dignitatis Humanae, the Vatican II document on  religious liberty. And I would bet that the vast majority of the critics of AL have not profoundly assimilated this teaching of the Council.  At the basis of Dignitatis Humanae is a teaching about conscience that is very much tied to what AL teaches about conscience. DH teaches that  religion is essentially something inward; AL teaches that morality is essentially something inward, that it is not essentially about the merely external keeping of rules. At the base of both is a conception of conscience which is Biblical and ecclesiastical, but at the same time inward and personalist. The Church has been moving in this direction, and Pope Francis is struggling to keep us moving.

Comment: "He had been the first Territorial Governor of Oregon (after Lincoln declined) "
No Mr. Walsh,   Lincoln did not "decline" the position of first Territorial Governor  of Oregon.   In 1848  Lane, a D,  was appointed Territorial Governor  by Democratic President Polk who would never have dreamed  of appointing Lincoln, a Whig.  Later Lincoln  campaigned heavily for the Whig  presidential candidate Gen. Zachary Taylor with the hope he'd be appointed  head  of the Government Land Office.
While Taylor won, he only proposed Lincoln as Oregon's Secretary of State, which he declined; Taylor then offered the  territorial governor's position but Lincoln declined that also.  Taylor then in 1850  appointed a fellow Whig, John Gaines, who proved to be rather unpopular in this largely Democratic state.
Why did Lincoln reject Taylor's offer  to be our second Territorial Governor?  Possibly because he'd have no political future in a largely D state, or  because Mary didn't want to "Go  way out West."

Comment: We live on an island paradise, so I believe we need to set stricter environmental and building code standards. We are overbuilding, encouraging denser living with our ADU program and allowing massive housing projects on prime agricultural lands. Everyone says we need more housing for "locals", but we will never be able to build enough housing because people all over the world want to move here, and as soon as something is built, it goes to the highest bidder. As our world population grows and more people are mobile and have big money to spend on real estate, values of prime land is skyrocketing and people who buy for investment want to max out the building footprint on their property. I suggest a comprehensive master plan that includes more environmental and social impacts of our zoning laws, and we need to stop blaming vacation rentals as the reason for all our woes and think about regulating owner-occupied rentals so residents can keep their houses and the State can get more revenue.

Comment: Go back to 1996 and look at the record.  There were plenty of reputable, non-partisan experts that supported the CDC's research. It was the NRA -- hardly an unbiased arbiter --  that accused CDC researchers of promoting gun control and then used its tremendous political clout to shut down the research. Of course the NRA is going to call it dishonest and fraudulent -- that's the job of an "advocacy" group. I have far more faith in the neutrality of the CDC, which is something that is required in its charter. Right now, any gun violence statistics that are cited -- including homicides, suicides, accidental shootings, etc., are based on piecemeal data collection -- there is no central repository of gun violence data. The CDC, whatever you think of it, has the resources to fill that role. The NRA is simply doing what any smart lawyer does -- petition to have the evidence thrown out of there is any minute chance that it may hurt your case. Good lawyering, but bad public policy.

Comment: What?  If someone had threatened to go to police but didn't, that's not "the same" as actually going to police and reporting a crime.  If somebody did actually go to police multiple times to report sexual assaults by multiple men, the police would have a record of that and act accordingly.  But we don't know if that has ever actually happened.  In contrast, I'm talking about a real case of a serial rapist, and in that case, all 3 complainants had gone to police before he was caught and charged and the press reported it.  

The bottom line is that most people who are charged with crimes including sexual assault never have their names published unless they are convicted, and even then it's not likely to make the evening paper.  We only hear about the more serious cases.  It's a red herring.

Comment: The way commentators are carrying on about the recent interest rate increase by the Bank of Canada, one would almost think that they sky is about to fall.  Many years ago, a 1/4  per cent increase in interest rates was barely noticed. Even a 1 per cent increase over the span of several months didn't cause much alarm. But, these days household debt is huge compared to where it was when I bought my condominium in 1990 (a three year mortgage, at 12 per cent). My generation was much more wary of non-mortgage debt, so  most of us tried to avoid it as much as possible. Now, it seems that many younger adults have no idea how to manage a household budget and debt instruments,  or how to save money, hence the near panic over small interest rate increases. Comment: Typical statutes might differentiate between the two as follows:

First Degree: intent to kill + premeditation and deliberation

Second Degree:  intentional killing; by extremely reckless conduct, intent to cause serious bodily harm, Deadly weapon doctrine 

I could easily imagine that this cop did not set out to work that day with the intent to kill anybody, nor did he do any planning for the murder, making it hard to get a conviction for First Degree Murder. 

But, a pretty good case might be made that the killing was "spur of the moment" (perhaps out of anger?), or something like that.  

So had the charge been second degree, I think the cop may have had a tougher go in court.  A conviction would require a lot of time in jail, possibly for life.  So did the prosecutor overstep on this one?

Comment: "there is insufficient good science to support it."

There is also insufficient science to refute claims of toxic impact on Hawaii's people and environment.  In large part, the lack of conclusive evidence is due to lack of data about the use of industrial pesticides in Hawaii.  That's one reason mandatory reporting of pesticide applications is needed.

There is ample ascorbic evidence that these pesticides are neurotoxic (that's how they kill insects), and can harm developing brains of children.  That's why medical experts recommend children avoid any exposure. 

Buffer zones near schools and residential areas just makes common sense until these toxins can be proven safe.

By the way, protecting this risky industry makes little sense. For all the controversy has created, you would think the seed industry is a major part of our economy. In fact, it only generates around $15 million in annual tax revenue for the state.

Comment: muralind, 

Assuming we agree it is the U.S. Constitution that establishes our form of government, where in it does it actually state that our three branches of government, the Executive, the Legislative, and the Judicial are in fact co-equal?  I know our government is commonly thought of that way, and indeed even Harvard-educated former president Barack Obama made mention of it in his book The Audacity of Hope.  But other than delineating what each branch of government is responsible for, exactly where is it expressly stated in the Constitution that this is so?   In fact, can you show us where the word "co-equal" even appears in the text of the U.S. Constitution or the Bill of Rights? 

My reading of the Federalist Papers makes it quite clear that the Founding Fathers intended the Legislative Branch to be preeminant. 

I realize that as children many of us are TOLD there are three co-equal branches of government.  But are there really?  If so, you'd think it would appear in writing.

Comment: Let's address a few things:

1.  This is not an argument about whether there should be a minimum wage or not (in my opinion there should be, and that is a whole separate conversation).

3.  The Card-Krueger analyses, while reasonably well-executed, are specific to their data sets which include: small increase ($.80/hr), relatively short timeframes pre/post increase, and were limited to national players in very specific industries - e.g. fast food.   No one has demonstrated that they are directly relevant to Ontario

Comment: Social Security "retirement" payments are not truly adjusted for inflation.....and neither should PERA's be. 
-
The "COLA for Social Security adjustments" had been "downgraded" from the "true Inflation Rate" for years now. In fact - in fact - there has been years where a the Social Security payment from one year to another has been flat.....with no increase.....and even has seen a "significant decrease".... even though the Official Inflation Rate for the year was 3%, 4%, and even 5%. 
-
Why? Because The Government saves money even if The Government "screws" those on Social Security. The main way it does so is by "keeping the Gross Social Security payment" "the same" from one year to the next.....but then charges more for Medicare that is automatically deducted.....so the result is that the Social Security payee can and does actually lose - lose - money each month.
-
Perhaps if PERA adjusted its "COLA" using the Social Security Formula.....it wouldn't go insolvent quite as fast.

Comment: I understood but others took it seriously, invoking FMCG companies. My serious point was private companies, particularly SA ones that don't have a good history even w/ non-public goods, running essential services is a bad idea. No, for now state-run infrastructure and distribution is best. Cape Town's mess is dt the city's incompetence and negligence. They've good engineers but clueless politicians, eg. former speech writers, unionists, etc are undermining them by NOT providing strategic direction. Cf the situation w/ rail - political stasis. What other explanation do you have? NB private companies are still involved designing infrastructure and as contractors - not the state, which is the client - so they're still involved.

Comment: The precedent in these cases was made in 2007 by Stephen Harper, when he awarded Maher Arar $10.5 million for the government's role in the brutal mistreatment he received.  (On incorrect information provided by the Canadian government, Maher Arar was detained by US officials and deported to a Syrian prison. There he was incarcerated for about a year, and tortured. The cost of that horrible mistake was $10.5 million in compensation.)

As for Omar Khadr, Canadian officials were complicit in his torture when he was but 16 years old. He endured almost 10 years confinement in Guantanamo, before serving an addition 5 years in Canadian maximum and medium security prisons. At every turn his rights were willfully ignored by the Canadian government. For that we're getting off lightly at $10.5M.

Omar's guilt or innocence are of no consequence in this matter. He paid his debt to society for any transgressions he may have made. Now it's time for society to pay for ours.
